repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Influenza Emergency Preparedness and Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Influenza Emergency Preparedness and Control
            Project for Haiti were as follows: overall outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, and both the Bank and the Borrower performance
            were moderately unsatisfactory. The following are among the
            more important project lessons: (1) Close coordination and
            cooperation between animal health and human health are key
            to successful implementation of investments. (2) The
            establishment of a medium to long-term prevention and
            control program is required. The lesson for this project and
            other animal health interventions is that even if responding
            to a disease specific emergency, interventions also need to
            focus on systemic improvements and basic capacity building
            which are sustainable in the medium to long term. (3)
            Mitigation measures to close a financing gap should be part
            of appraisal. (4) Institutional strengthening in project
            management is the pillar to success in fragile contexts, in
            particular for emergency operations. (5) A flexible and
            timely response is critical.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Influenza Emergency Preparedness and Control Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to minimize
            the threat posed by AHI infection and other diseases for the
            poultry sector and humans, and to prepare for, control, and
            respond to influenza pandemics and other infectious disease
            emergencies as they may occur. The project aims to support
            the implementation of preventive measures and strengthening
            infrastructure for early detection and rapid response to
            health emergencies constituted by the highly pathogenic
            avian influenza (HPAI). The initial focus of activities is
            on animal health and emergency animal health preparedness
            and prevention activities, and capacity building at multiple
            levels in several key areas (laboratory facilities and
            community-based interventions), with some limited actions
            concerning human health. This project is expected to
            contribute to minimizing or mitigating the impacts of an
            unchecked Avian-Human Influenza (AHI) outbreak and help
            avert a human pandemic, through the development of a viable
            and effective reporting and response mechanisms. It is not
            expected to have any large-scale, significant, or
            irreversible impacts, as it is focused largely on capacity
            building and the strengthening of emergency preparedness,
            readiness and response to AHI.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Influenza Emergency Preparedness and Control Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Avian Influenza
            Control and Human Influenza Emergency Preparedness and
            Control Project for Haiti is to minimize the threat posed to
            humans by highly-pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) infection
            and other zoonoses, and to prepare for, control, and respond
            to influenza pandemics and other infectious disease
            emergencies in humans. Objective indicators do not change
            but the targets are modified because the base line has
            changed, as well as the depth of activities to be conducted
            with the reallocation of proceeds for the strengthening of
            the Ministry of Agriculture, Natural Resources and Rural
            Development (MARNDR). Particularly the following targets
            will change in the objective indicators of the project: (i)
            one third (instead of half) of communal sections will send
            weekly reports on time; and (ii) 1500 (instead of 2800)
            backyard poultry farmers currently applying at least three
            prescriptions to protect their poultry and/or family of
            Avian Influenza diseases. The reallocation is based on: (i)
            the need to strengthen animal and human health activities;
            and (ii) the need to replace equipment and materials damaged
            by the earthquake at the Central Bio-safety Laboratory in
            Port au Prince.
